questions.text: Postpartum decidual secretions present are referred to as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Lochia is the normal postpartum uterine discharge composed of blood, mucus, and necrotic decidual tissue
  • It occurs in three phases: lochia rubra (first 3-4 days), lochia serosa (up to day 10), and lochia alba (up to 6 weeks)

Explanation of other options:

Bleeding per vaginum (Option B): A nonspecific term; does not refer exclusively to the normal postpartum discharge seen after delivery.

Vasa previa (Option C): An antepartum complication where fetal vessels cross the cervical os; not associated with postpartum changes

Decidua capsularis (Option D): Part of the decidua during early pregnancy that covers the chorionic sac; not shed as postpartum lochia

Key Takeaways:

  • Lochia is a physiological postpartum discharge
  • Contains blood, mucus, and decidual remnants
  • Important to differentiate from pathological bleeding

questions.text: Likely size of uterus at 8 weeks postpartum is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The uterus weighs ~1000 g immediately after delivery
  • By 1 week postpartum, weight reduces to ~500 g
  • By 2 weeks postpartum, the weight is around 300 g
  • By 4 weeks postpartum, it reaches ~100 g, the pre-pregnant weight
  • At 8 weeks postpartum, the uterus has completed involution, so its weight remains ~100 g

Key Takeaways:

  • Uterus returns to pre-pregnant size (~100 g) by 8 weeks postpartum
  • Involution occurs via a reduction in muscle fiber size
  • Weight reduction follows a predictable pattern over 6-8 weeks

questions.text: A pregnant female develops an embolism just after delivery. What medical management should she take?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Venous thromboembolism (VTE) is a major cause of maternal morbidity and mortality postpartum
  • Management includes initiating IV heparin and oral warfarin postpartum
  • Warfarin is started 6–8 hours after vaginal delivery, and 24 hours after cesarean section
  • Once INR reaches 2–3, heparin is discontinued, and warfarin is continued for 6 weeks
  • Warfarin is safe during lactation

Explanation of other options:

Immediate use of aspirin (Option A): Ineffective for treating postpartum embolism; not part of standard VTE treatment

No treatment needed (Option B): Dangerous; embolism is a medical emergency requiring anticoagulation

Only bed rest and observation (Option C): Insufficient and risky without anticoagulation

Key Takeaways:

  • Heparin + warfarin are used to manage postpartum VTE
  • Warfarin is safe during breastfeeding
  • Therapy continues for at least 6 weeks postpartum

questions.text: A decrease in lactation is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Maternal anxiety can suppress the oxytocin reflex, impairing milk letdown
  • Cracked nipple causes painful suckling, leading to reduced frequency of feeding, thus lowering milk production
  • Breast abscess can cause pain, inflammation, and may require cessation of feeding from the affected breast, reducing lactation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Lactation is hormonally and behaviorally regulated.d
  • Pain, infection, and stress all contribute to reduced milk output
  • Management includes treating the underlying cause and supporting effective suckling

questions.text: The contraceptive method of choice in lactating mothers is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Barrier method (Option A): Higher failure rate; not the most reliable for contraception in lactating women
  • Progesterone only pill (Option B): Preferred method; does not affect milk production, is safe during breastfeeding, and low risk of thromboembolism
  • Oral contraceptive pills (Option C): Contain estrogen, which may reduce milk supply and increase thromboembolic risk, especially in the early postpartum period
  • Lactational amenorrhea (Option D): Unreliable unless exclusive breastfeeding, with regular intervals and no supplementary feeding; ovulation may occur before menstruation resumes.

Key Takeaways:

  • Progestin-only contraceptives are safe and effective for lactating mothers
  • Estrogen-containing OCPs are avoided early postpartum due to milk suppression and VTE risk
  • IUCDs are suitable only after uterine involution (typically after 6 weeks)

choices.text: The patient may continue breastfeeding at her own risk
The patient should breastfeed her baby only if her INR is <2.5
The patient can breastfeed her baby after the 6-week course of warfarin is over
Warfarin is not a contraindication for lactation

questions.text: Sarita, a 30-year-old woman, develops a deep vein thrombosis in her left calf on the fourth postoperative day following a caesarean section done for foetal distress. The patient is started on heparin and is scheduled to begin a 6-week course of warfarin therapy. The patient is a devoted mother who wants to breastfeed her baby. What advice can be given to the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Warfarin is not excreted in significant quantities into breast milk and is considered safe during lactation
  • Recommended in postpartum anticoagulation after initial heparin in cases like DVT
  • Supported by Williams Obstetrics and ACOG guidelines

Explanation of other options:

Patient may continue breastfeeding at her own risk (Option A): Misleading and incorrect; there is no risk with warfarin in lactation.

The patient should breastfeed her baby only if her INR is <2.5 (Option B): INR monitoring is for maternal anticoagulation control, not related to breastfeeding safety.

Patient can breastfeed baby after the 6 6-weekourse of warfarin is over (Option C): Unnecessary restriction; breastfeeding can and should continue during warfarin therapy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Warfarin is safe for breastfeeding mothers
  • INR level does not impact breastfeeding safety
  • No need to delay or avoid breastfeeding while on warfarin

choices.text: Breastfeed from the unaffected breast only
Immediately start antibiotics and breastfeed only when antibiotics are discontinued.
Pump and discard breast milk until the infection is over, and then continue breastfeeding.

questions.text: A 24-year-old P2+0 woman presents to the emergency department complaining of pain in her right breast. The patient is postpartum day 10 from an uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery at 42 weeks. She reports no difficulty breastfeeding for the first several days postpartum, but states that for the past week her daughter has had difficulty latching on. Three days ago, her right nipple became dry and cracked, and since yesterday, it has become increasingly swollen and painful. Her temperature is 38.3°C (101°F). Her right nipple and areola are warm, swollen, red, and tender. There is no fluctuance or induration, and no pus can be expressed from the nipple.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Clinical presentation suggests mastitis: fever, unilateral breast pain, erythema, tenderness, and cracked nipple
  • Mastitis is not a contraindication to breastfeeding
  • Continued breastfeeding aids milk drainage, prevents engorgement, and supports recovery
  • Empirical antibiotics (e.g., dicloxacillin or cephalexin) are given, but breastfeeding should be continued during treatment

Explanation of other options:

Breastfeed from the unaffected breast only (Option B): Inadequate; continuing to nurse from the affected side helps relieve obstruction and infection.

Immediately start antibiotics and breastfeed only when antibiotics are discontinued (Option C): Incorrect; antibiotics compatible with lactation are used, and breastfeeding should continue. ue

Pump and discard breast milk till infection is over, and then continue breastfeeding (Option D): Unnecessary and may decrease milk supply; direct breastfeeding is preferred.

Key Takeaways:

  • Mastitis does not warrant stopping breastfeeding
  • Continued breastfeeding from both breasts is therapeutic
  • Treat with antibiotics while maintaining lactation

questions.text: Common route of spread of puerperal sepsis:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Puerperal sepsis refers to infection of the genital tract following delivery
  • Direct invasion is the most common route of spread-pathogens ascend from vagina/cervix to uterus, particularly at the placental site.
  • Lymphatic spread can occur, but is less common (Option A ruled out)
  • Skip lesions are not a recognized mode of infection spread in puerperal sepsis (Option C ruled out)
  • Hematogenous spread is rare and more typical of systemic infections, not initial puerperal sepsis (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Direct spread is the primary route in puerperal sepsis
  • Common site: placental bed; common organism: Streptococcus
  • Cesarean section significantly increases the risk

questions.text: M/C nerve injured during normal vaginal delivery is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is most commonly injured during normal vaginal delivery due to compression or traction, especially in prolonged labor or semi-Fowler positioning
  • Risk factors include nulliparity, prolonged second stage, and pushing in a semi-sitting position

Explanation of other options:

Femoral nerve (Option A): Less commonly affected; injury may occur with extreme hip flexion or instrumental delivery

Iliohypogastric nerve (Option C): More commonly injured during cesarean section rather than vaginal delivery

Ilioinguinal nerve (Option D): Also typically affected during surgical procedures like cesarean, not during spontaneous vaginal birth

Key Takeaways:

  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve injury is the most common during vaginal delivery.
  • Injury associated with the prolonged second stage, semi-Fowler position
  • Iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal nerves are more prone to injury in cesarean section

questions.text: For the first 2 hrs after delivery, temperature should be recorded:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the first 2 hours postpartum, BP and pulse are monitored every 15 minutes
  • Temperature is recorded every 4 hours during the first 8 hours after delivery
  • This helps in the early detection of puerperal complications such as sepsis or hemorrhage

Key Takeaways:

  • Temperature monitoring: every 4 hours for the first 8 hours postpartum
  • BP and pulse: every 15 minutes for the first 2 hours
  • Part of the routine postpartum observation protocol

choices.text: Administration of a single dose of ampicillin or 1st generation cephalosporin at the time of cesarean delivery.
Skin closure with staples rather than with suture

questions.text: Which of the following steps has proven benefit in decreasing puerperal infection following cesarean section?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Prophylactic antibiotics, particularly a single dose of ampicillin or first-generation cephalosporin, have proven benefit in reducing post-cesarean uterine infections
  • This step significantly lowers the risk of endometritis and wound infections

Explanation of other options:

Non-closure of peritoneum (Option A): May reduce operative time, but has no proven benefit in infection prevention

Single-layer uterine closure (Option B): A surgical preference; not associated with reduced infection rates

Skin closure with staples rather than with suture (Option D): Staples may increase wound complications, and do not reduce infection risk compared to sutures

Key Takeaways:

  • Antibiotic prophylaxis is the only proven intervention to lower cesarean-related infections.
  • Timing: just before or at the time of incision
  • Other surgical techniques do not influence infection risk
